journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: Integrated workflow for multi-objective evolutionary optimization of the vehicle tyre parameters

article-meta.aff: 1Michelin Centre de Technologies Europe, Ladoux, Clermont-Ferrand, France
2Ecole Centrale de Lyon, Laboratoire de Tribologie et de Dynamique des Systèmes, Equipe Dynamique des Structures et des Systèmes, Ecully, France

author-notes.corresp: Frederic Gillot, Ecole Centrale de Lyon, 36 Avenue Guy de Collongue, Ecully 69130, France. Email: frederic.gillot@ec-lyon.fr

permissions.copyright-statement: © Ecole Centrale de Lyon, French Ministry for Education and Research 2013

abstract.p: An integrated workflow based on a multi-objective evolutionary optimization algorithm combined with an automatic post-treatment of optimal solutions is presented. This workflow enables a fast pre-design of the vehicle tyre and suspension parameters to be achieved. Such optimization involves usually more than five objective functions. In this case, classical multi-objective approaches are not very successful in providing the designer automatically and quickly with a limited set of Pareto-optimal solutions. In this paper, the proposed workflow is applied to help during the pre-design of the tyre dimensions. Tyres have to fulfil about ten different specifications from road handling to rolling resistance. The results are given as a limited set of solutions, hence providing very powerful decision support for the designer.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The pre-design of mechanical products can usually be formalized as a multi-objective optimization problem, where the different specifications are represented by objective functions. Several methods are available to reach optimal designs, from the optimization of a weighted sum of objectives to multi-objective optimization approaches based on metaheuristics. The latter successfully improves the design process as it allows determination of a very large number of trade-offs on the so-called Pareto front.1 Moreover, the importance given to any objective does not have to be specified a priori.

Among the available metaheuristics, evolutionary algorithms are popular for the pre-design step since no special assumption concerning the objective functions is required for convergence. Unfortunately, the larger the number of objectives that the designer wants to take into account, the higher the computing cost will be. Moreover, the generated Pareto front must be treated so as to observe only a few solutions on which a decision will be achieved. This problem has been addressed by some researchers,2 but so far no integrated approaches have been entirely described. Difficulties still rely on the integration of a specific algorithm able to treat problems with ‘many objectives’ (in the work by Deb and Tiwari,3 more than four objectives) quickly, with a data-mining process able to treat a fully populated Pareto front and to provide the designer with a limited set of solutions.

The industrial design lead time has been progressively reduced for more than a decade in order to bring new products to the market rapidly. This has been made possible because of product redesign since specifications of new products have been kept unchanged during this period. Nevertheless, environmental regulations are becoming increasingly stringent, and the importance given to energy efficiency in the design of new products increases from day to day. Therefore, the design process has to be reconsidered in order to be able to design products that have to fulfil new specifications compared with their former version quickly.

Hence, we propose in this article to describe an integrated workflow for multi-objective evolutionary optimization of tyre dimensions when designing a new vehicle. First, an overview of the proposed workflow is given in the second section. After describing the impact of the tyre dimensions on the vehicle properties in the third section, then we detail the optimization algorithm in the fourth section. The Pareto-front automatic clustering tool is described in the fifth section before presenting a summary of the results obtained for the tyre design. Finally, we discuss the results and the relevancy of the proposed approach.

sec.title: Workflow overview
sec.p: The proposed workflow scheme is given in Figure 1. It is divided into two parts. The first part concerns the optimization algorithm, and the second part the data-mining algorithm. Results are automatically generated as limited sets of optimal typings.

caption.p: Proposed workflow scheme. Nc and Ns are conditions on the number of generations required to know which type of model will be used to evaluate the objective functions. Nmax is the stopping condition for the total number of generations

sec.p: Concerning the optimization algorithm, it is based on a specific genetic algorithm containing a hybrid fitness function using both Pareto optimality and Pareto efficiency. It enables many objectives (more than five objective functions) to be treated.4 Furthermore, surrogate modelling is integrated in the optimization process in order to accelerate evaluations of the objective functions while maintaining a good accuracy. Such an optimization algorithm is able to treat numerous specifications described by computationally expensive models and to generate a set of Pareto-optimal solutions after convergence.

In the case of a high-dimension pre-design step problem, the multi-dimensional Pareto front obtained is nearly impossible to observe with classical visualization techniques. A decision support tool is necessary to help the designer to select the solutions which best match its specification. Unfortunately, the majority of available tools require at least one solution to be decided by a human operator, usually empirically. Thus, we propose to build an automatic clustering tool based on self-organizing maps (SOMs) so as to synthesize the multiple optimal solutions into a reduced number of typings.

sec.title: Pre-design of the tyre dimensions
sec.p: Tyres have several functions, when mounted on a vehicle. Indeed, they are the only parts to be in contact with the road. As a result, it is important to ensure that the tyre responses to various driver inputs involves stability and cornering capability for good handling. Furthermore, it is also important for safety reasons to ensure good braking performances whether in wet or in dry conditions. For the same reason, it is important to check that aquaplaning does not appear for low speeds. Furthermore, since tyres are involved in the vehicle’s fuel consumption because of the rolling resistance, it is important to consider this performance in the design process. Customers are also interested in tread wear because it is costly to change tyres very often. Finally, tyres are responsible for passenger comfort as well and so it is important to consider each of these performances in the design process since they are almost all antagonistic.

sec.title: Model descriptions
sec.p: The tyre pre-design that we consider in this article deals with the tyre dimensions (Table 1). The design variables are summarized in Table 2. For each combination of these design variables, it is possible to evaluate the performance criteria described above. Table 3 summarizes all the corresponding objective functions that are to be taken into account during the multi-objective optimization. The models used to describe all these objective functions will be discussed in this part.

caption.p: Design space for the problem of the pre-design of tyre dimensions.
Description of the performances that are to be taken into account during the pre-design process for the tyre dimensions

sec.title: Road handling
sec.p: Road handling is a subjective performance which is difficult to simulate.5 Nevertheless we shall consider here two criteria to guarantee the cornering capability as well as the cornering stability of the vehicle. A schematic diagram of the well-known single-track vehicle model used to simulate handling behaviour is given in Figure 2. In this representation, lF and lR are the distance between the centre of gravity, labelled G, and the front axle and the distance between G and the rear axle respectively. R is the bend radius, α is the steering angle, and δF and δR are the front-axle drift angle and the rear-axle drift angle respectively. In this model, it is considered that, for each axle, the lateral force Fy is linked to the drift angle by the formula

caption.p: Bicycle model used to model road handling of the vehicle in the moderate-speed condition.

sec.p: As a result, the drift angles can be calculated on each axle according to
where mF and mR are the front-axle mass and the rear-axle mass respectively and γ is the vehicle’s acceleration.
It is now possible to represent the cornering capability CC of the vehicle as the ratio of the drift angle on the rear axle to the acceleration as given by
The cornering stability CS is a criterion based on the difference in the drift angles according to

Both the criteria CC and CS are able to characterize the handling behaviour of the vehicle and each car manufacturer specifies its own target. Therefore, the objective functions that we consider here are the deviation between the cornering capability CC and the cornering stability CS and their relative targets

sec.title: Fuel consumption
sec.p: Over the last decade, the importance of energy efficiency has increased in the design process. We consider here two objective functions in order to take into account this performance. Here, the two criteria which are to be minimized are the fuel consumption values over two driving cycles. The first driving cycle that we consider is the so-called New European Driving Cycle (NEDC), which is a normative cycle. The second driving cycle is the assessment and reliability of transport emission models and inventory systems (ARTEMIS) urban driving cycle,6 which is more likely to represent urban driving conditions. The two driving cycles are shown in Figures 3 and 4 respectively.

caption.p: Time–speed diagram of the vehicle for the NEDC.
Time–speed diagram of the vehicle for the ARTEMIS urban driving cycle.

sec.p: Tyres play a role in fuel consumption because of their rolling resistances and their inertias. As a result, the objective functions considered to evaluate fuel consumption are calculated considering the rolling resistances and the inertias of the tyres and are given by

for the NEDC and the ARTEMIS urban driving cycle respectively. In these expressions, the terms θ and κ are empirical weights, which are associated with the rolling resistance and the inertia terms respectively and which depend on the driving cycle. It is possible to evaluate the inertia of a tyre and its wheel easily owing to proportional transformation from a known dimension. Also, the rolling resistances of tyres changes with the dimensions and the inflation pressure.

sec.title: Braking performance
sec.p:
The braking performance can be measured by the braking distance necessary to stop a vehicle. A difference is made here between wet and dry conditions since the braking distance depends on the surface properties. Nevertheless, braking is a complex phenomenon to model for an anti-lock braking system (ABS), which now exists on almost every vehicle. The longitudinal force FX generated by the tyre depends on the slippage rate τg, which is defined as the ratio of the wheel’s rolling speed at the contact point on the road to the vehicle speed. The aim of an ABS is to avoid locking the wheels and to keep the tyre slippage rate between 0% and 30%. Indeed, it can be seen in Figure 5 that it allows the best grip performance. The objective function that we consider in this part to evaluate the braking performance is the average friction coefficient
μ
¯
between the tyre and the road for slippage rates between 0% and 30% as given by

caption.p: Schematic diagram representing evolution of the friction coefficient as a function of the slippage ratio in dry conditions.

sec.p: In this expression, the way that lateral forces are calculated depends on the surface. Indeed, the thermally dependent elastic and viscous properties of rubber make the tyre characteristics strongly dependent on the temperature. Therefore the operating condition history is important to evaluate accurate forces. Since braking on dry surfaces generates much more heat than braking on wet surfaces does, it is necessary here to differentiate between the two conditions.

sec.title: Aquaplaning
sec.p: The presence of water interferes with the grip mechanisms. Molecular adhesion can no longer operate if contact between the rubber of the tyres and the road surface is not perfectly clean and dry. In wet weather, maintaining grip therefore involves dispersing the water to restore dry contact between the tread and the road. Nevertheless, a speed exists at which aquaplaning occurs, i.e. at which the rubber is no longer in contact with the road surface. The objective function faquap is simply the speed at which aquaplaning occurs. It is calculated using

and following the assumptions detailed by Wies et al.7 In this expression, χ is a coefficient, which depends on the road roughness as well as the tyre tread pattern characteristics. l and L are the width and the length respectively of the tread pattern and therefore depend on the dimensions, the inflation pressure pF and the vehicle load.

sec.title: Wear
sec.p: Rubber wear is the result of several different mechanisms that range from rubber oxidation to mechanical delamination. All or some of these mechanisms may be present at the same time, thus making it very difficult to construct a predictive and practical model for rubber wear. Moreover, rubber wear is a function of a huge variety of external parameters, such as the shape of the contacting surfaces, the presence of contaminants between these surfaces, the sliding speed, the normal pressure and the contact temperature.8 The objective function fwear that we shall consider in this section links the frictional power to the height loss Δh of the rubber on the tread according to
with
and

In these expressions, the frictional power in the longitudinal direction and the frictional power in the lateral direction are denoted Wx and Wy respectively.

are empirical coefficients depending on the road surface as well as the rubber compounds. Finally, V is the velocity, τg is the slippage rate and δ′ is the slip angle of the tread.

sec.title: Comfort
sec.p: Comfort is here characterized by the objective function fcomf, which consists of the wheel hop frequency and is to be minimized. The expression for this objective function is
where KZZ is the tyre radial stiffness, which depends on the section width B, the external diameter Dext and the inflation pressure p according to

sec.title: Problem formalization
sec.p: At this stage, we have briefly described all the objective functions that we aim to take into account during the multi-objective optimization process. A thermomechanical model of the tyre is necessary to evaluate the longitudinal and lateral forces for every solution. The selected model here is the TaMeTirE model9 developed by Michelin. The inputs of this model are physical parameters which can be calculated for different tyre dimensions by considering proportional transformations.

Since the behaviour of a tyre strongly depends on the vehicle on which it is mounted, it is necessary to define a vehicle for this study. Therefore in this article we chose to use a standard front-wheel-drive vehicle with a combustion engine which has a mass of 1400 kg. Typical dimensions for tyres used on this kind of vehicle are a section width of 195 mm, an aspect ratio of 65%, a rim diameter of 15 in, a rim width of 6 in and an inflation pressure of 2.3 bar for tyres on both axles. These dimensions are now considered as reference values and all the objective functions will be scaled from them according to

where
f
^
is the scaled value of the objective function, f is its absolute value. Δf is a scaling factor and represents an improvement of 1% in the corresponding objective function f.

Finally, we shall here define a constraints set in order to obtain only the relevant solutions after optimization. Since new regulations have recently emerged about fuel consumption, braking in wet conditions as well as comfort, stringent constraints are considered for these performances. Other constraints have been set for the remaining performances in order to control their deterioration. The constraint thresholds considered in this article are summarized in Table 4.

caption.p: Constraint thresholds defined to control optimized solutions. These constraints are defined on the basis of the reference dimensions, and the threshold values were scaled.

sec.title: Optimization tool
sec.p: The mechanical products pre-design step usually consists in finding solutions satisfying a high number of specifications, described by objective functions, which are commonly antagonistic. Among approaches currently available to find those solutions, metaheuristics have emerged since they are exploration techniques and are able to reach multiple attainable trade-offs. Evolutionary algorithms10 are very popular among metaheuristics because their encoding is straightforward. The convergence of evolutionary algorithms is driven by their fitness function, which is constructed to select the best individuals at each generation.

This selection can be achieved because of either Pareto-optimality considerations3,11 or Pareto-efficiencyconsiderations.12 Pareto-optimality rank corresponds to the rank of the Pareto hyperplan frontier containing the considered individual. Pareto-optimality-based evolutionary algorithms using book keeping present low computational requirements.10 For example, the second version11 of the so-called non-sorting genetic algorithm (NSGA-II) presents an
O ( M
N
2
)
complexity (M is the number of objectives, and N is the number of individuals considered at each generation), instead of at least
O ( M
N
3
)
for other classical evolutionary algorithms. Pareto optimality is combined with a crowding distance measure used to avoid niching phenomena and maintains a good diversity of solutions. Nevertheless the Pareto optimality selection efficacy decreases as the number of objective functions increases. On the other hand, Pareto efficiency is more elitist at the expense of its complexity.12 An individual is efficient of order k if it is Pareto optimal in all the
C
m
k
subspaces of the objective space obtained considering only k objectives at a time, where m represents the number of objectives. Indeed, Pareto optimality looks for solutions which optimize simultaneously the maximum number of objectives. It is here noticeable that Pareto efficiency is an extension of Pareto optimality; thus the rank calculated through this method is more accurate as a fitness function than the Pareto-optimality rank itself. Nevertheless, this ranking method is also more computer time expensive since it is necessary to generate combinatorial subspaces of objectives and to test the Pareto optimality of solutions on each of them. Pareto efficiency has been introduced, for example, in the preference ordering genetic algorithm12 (POGA). The diversity of solutions is preserved using the crowding distance criterion in addition.

sec.title: Pareto-front-generating algorithm
sec.p: In order to deal with a large number of objective functions as rapidly as possible, we have developed a specific fitness function, which combines the advantages of the Pareto-optimality ranking approach in terms of the convergence speed with the advantages of the Pareto-efficiency ranking approach in terms of the accuracy. Genetic operators as well as mutation are similar to those in the NSGA-II algorithm. Our specific fitness function is given by

This expression is the combination of a Pareto-optimality integer term GPO and a decimal Pareto-efficiency term GPE. The GPO term defines several fronts from solutions based on their Pareto-optimality rank similarly to the approach in NSGA-II. Also, another ranking is operated on each front based on the Pareto efficiency with GPE, which is the rank employed in the POGA. As GPO is to be minimized and GPE is to be maximized to reach the optimal solutions, the two terms are concatenated into the fitness rank G* which is to be minimized.

As the optimization process begins, solutions are well spread over all the objective space and the selection is primarily conducted on GPO. Hence, the process is speeded up because of the effective book keeping. Then, once the algorithm starts to converge to Pareto-optimal solutions, the selection is made on the GPE term, which is more elitist and enables preferentially solutions to be kept; this simultaneously optimizes several objectives. Furthermore, the crowding distance criterion is preserved to maintain a good diversity of trade-offs during the convergence. Our proposed fitness function is then well suited to problems with many objectives and generates quickly a fully populated Pareto front even for problems with more than four objective functions.

sec.title: Surrogate modelling integration
sec.p: Several approaches have been developed in order to overcome expensive model techniques, such as finite element simulations, within the optimization loop.13 Among these approaches, surrogate modelling tools such as polynomial regression, radial basis function or kriging14,15 can improve noticeably the computational cost of model techniques. Nevertheless, the larger the design space that the surrogate model has to cover, the lower is the accuracy of the result.

To overcome this drawback, we considered both surrogate and original models to make the objective evaluations more rapid while avoiding loss of accuracy due to a large concept space. This kind of approach has proved to be very efficient in the case of complex model techniques.14

Within the proposed workflow, individuals of the first generation are obtained with the original models and are used to build a surrogate model with the kriging method.16 Kriging is here proposed from among the surrogate modelling techniques since it performs well on multi-dimensional data.14 Moreover, it is capable of representing non-linear models with a restricted number of points. In order to improve the accuracy of the surrogate model during the optimization process, the objective evaluation is split up into surrogate models and original models following the scheme described in Figure 6.

caption.p: Objective evaluation scheme during the optimization process. Nc and Ns are the number of generations relying on the original modelling and the number of generations relying on the surrogate modelling respectively.

sec.p: The original models and surrogate models are used for objective evaluation for Nc and Ns generations respectively until convergence. The definition of Nc has to be achieved considering the number of data necessary to construct a sufficiently accurate surrogate model and hence depends on the number of individuals chosen per generation. Similarly, the definition of Ns will strongly depend on the performance of the surrogate model. It is improved each time that the model has to be calculated for Nc generations, as the model output is used to construct the enhanced surrogate model which will be used for the next Ns generations. In our case, we used empirical values for Nc and Ns for each model, in order to reach a satisfactory computational time.

Although no general rules can be given to implement this hybrid evaluation, this technique allows a large amount of time to be saved in reaching optimal solutions and thus is fully appreciable in the context of a mechanical products pre-design step.

sec.title: Optimization results and discussion
sec.p:
The problem described in the section on the pre-design of the tyre dimensions was solved using the proposed workflow. The optimization loop was carried out using 150 individuals over 1500 generations. The number of individuals and the number of generations are high because of the large number of objectives that we want to take into account in this study. The implementation of metamodels for each objective function allows convergence to be obtained in a reasonable computation time. Indeed, the computational time is more than 75% shorter with 95% of evaluations carried out with surrogate modelling. The Pareto front obtained by the optimization process is composed of 99 optimal solutions. Each individual x is defined by its genotype
x = [
x
1
, … ,
x
V
]
and its phenotype
f ( x ) = [
f
1
, … ,
f
M
]
, where V and M are the number of design variables and the number of objectives respectively.

Solutions can be visualized in Figure 7, which is a classical SOM of objectives and variables, normalized between 0 and 1. We relied on an artificial neural network using unsupervised learning to provide a two-dimensional and discretized representation (a map) of the input space of the training samples. Also, no difference is made between genotypic space (design parameters space) and phenotypic space (objectives space) to compute the distance. It is therefore possible to observe the link between the design parameters and the objectives among the optimal solutions from these pictures. Even with SOM representation, extracting a restricted amount of optimal solutions appears to be nearly impossible in seven dimensions.

caption.p: SOM visualization of the design variables as well as the obtained Pareto front of the tyres and suspensions pre-design problem. The coloured scale is given at the top on the right.

sec.title: Pareto-front clustering
sec.p: The previously described Pareto-front-generating approach was tailored to provide a large amount of optimal solutions as rapidly as possible. Hence, decision support tools became necessary to cluster multi-dimensional data as well as to visualize representative solutions of each cluster.

Pareto-front analysis can be achieved by several data-mining techniques, such as k-means;17 however, they require a priori knowledge about the population to be partitioned. Indeed, the performance of the latter with respect to the population strongly depends on its initialization with an a priori set-up of the number of clusters. Moreover, other classical tools such as hierarchical classification18 perform better to sort out larger databases with fewer dimensions than the population to be clustered.

sec.title: Automatic clustering tool
sec.p: We propose hence to use an automatic clustering approach in order to bring together similar solutions into a restricted number of clusters. We take advantage of the learning phase of the SOM method which already operates solution gathering to construct the automatic clustering algorithm. This algorithm relies on image processing to identify similarity regions automatically in the SOM distance matrix (D matrix19). The D matrix represents on a map the distance between a prototype vector and its neighbours. The similarity criterion is defined from a distance threshold which is optimized on the basis of the Davies–Bouldin index,20 which is a cluster quality index.
Once clusters have been obtained, we can define an artificial centre, a median individual and extreme individuals. For a cluster C, its artificial centre f* can be defined as
where NC is the number of individuals in cluster C and M is the number of objectives. The median individual is defined by
The extreme individuals xA and xB are defined as

We state that the median individual can be considered as the best ambassador of the cluster. In fact, clustering a fully populated Pareto front leads undoubtedly to lost information. Hence, we suppose that representing each cluster by its median and its two extreme individuals is sufficient, and a designer can then fully include the difference between the cluster representatives in order to make a choice.

sec.title: Clustering results and discussion
sec.p: The previously generated Pareto front for the problem described in the section on the pre-design of the tyre dimensions was post-treated with the proposed automatic clustering tool. This clustering approach enables us to propose a graphical representation of each cluster too, in order to obtain a better understanding of the differences between them.

Hence, it has been possible to downsize this Pareto front into a restricted number of typings. The clustering results in 10 clusters obtained from 250 individuals are shown in Figure 8. To the 99 individuals from the final Pareto front, we added 151 individuals from the book-keeping database to improve the sample size and diversity. Each cluster can be represented by its extreme individuals and its mean individual. For each cluster, we give the data in Table 5 for those three individuals.

caption.p: (a) The D matrix generated from the SOM of the Pareto front of the tyre dimensions pre-design problem. This matrix represents on a map the distance between a prototype vector and its neighbours. (b) Automatically clustered D matrix. 10 clusters were generated. Dark blue lines represent individuals which separate two clusters and hence which do not belong to any of these 10 clusters. We coloured each cluster for clarity.

The best representative clusters, where N is the cluster number and P is the number of individuals inside the considered cluster. For each cluster, the first two rows belong to its extreme individuals (see equation (19)), whereas the third row belongs to its mean individual (see equation (18)). The last three rows marked zero belong to outlier solutions, corresponding to bright points on the D matrix.

sec.p: It is now much easier for a designer to select one cluster from Table 5 and therefore one typing of a solution of the most interest. The best way to proceed at that point is to eliminate clusters that are considered to be less interesting. For example, if fuel consumption is of major importance, clusters 2, 7, 9 and 10 would be kept. It is then noticeable that the differences between these clusters are in the performances other than fuel consumption. The next step is probably to eliminate cluster 10 because of its poor aquaplaning performance compared with the other clusters. Among the remaining clusters, a trade-off exists between clusters 7 and 9 on the one hand and cluster 2 on the other hand, which have better performances in braking in wet conditions and a better performance in tyre wear respectively.

It is then noticeable that other trade-offs can be proposed. Indeed, cluster 8 is better balanced compared with the reference dimensions used to scale the performance values. Solutions which belong to this cluster are close to this reference and offer one of the best road-handling performances obtained because of the constraint set considered. One last cluster is interesting to describe since it offers improvements in both the aquaplaning performance and the tyre wear performance. It is the only cluster that allows such a trade-off between these performances. Others performances of this cluster are close to the reference values.

We represent in Figure 9 a parallel plot with 18 axes corresponding to design variables and objective functions values respectively. In this graph, median individuals of typings are displayed as bold lines, and extreme individuals as thin lines. The shaded areas defined between extreme individuals are added to obtain better visualization of each cluster range. It is noticeable from this representation that extreme individuals do not necessarily correspond to extreme values on each objective function. Only three typings are represented in Figure 9 for better readability. These three typings offer different trade-offs and the designer can easily choose the cluster of interest.

caption.p: Parallel plot of clusters obtained after the multi-objective optimization process. For each cluster, we represent a mean individual as a bold line. Also, a coloured area is defined between the two extreme individuals. In this representation, only three clusters are represented for clarity. Solutions which are shown in light brown belong to cluster 2, solutions in green are for cluster 6, and solutions in yellow are for cluster 8.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this paper we presented an integrated workflow for multi-objective evolutionary optimization of vehicle tyres and suspension parameters. The genetic algorithm implemented relies on a specific fitness function which enables us to deal with the high number of objectives that this kind of problem usually has. Constraint handling is allowed in this approach in order to obtain only relevant solutions for the designer. Moreover, surrogate models were integrated so as to speed up objective function evaluations which are usually expensive. An automatic post-treatment of Pareto-optimal solutions was proposed in order to synthesize a large multi-dimensional database into a restricted number of typings. This latter step is of particular importance since it affords a designer a powerful decision support tool to choose finally the best solution for a particular requirement.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.
